name: French Caribbean Music
description: Music from the French Antilles (Martinique, Guadeloupe, Dominica, Saint Lucia) and from Haiti.

children.name: Bele
children.description: Drum-based folkdance with a strong Afro-influence, conducted by duos of dancers and accompanied by call-and-response singing, particularly popular in Martinique, Dominica and Trinidad and Tobago.

children.name: Biguine
children.description: Dating back to the 19th century; originating as a fusion of traditional Bele music with Polka.

children.name: Bouyon
children.description: With a name translating to "broth", this fast-paced genre from Dominica originated as a blend of various traditional and modern Caribbean styles.

children.name: Cadence lypso
children.description: Caribbean genre originating in the 1970s, combining elements of Haiti's Cadence rampa and Compas with Trinidad's Calypso.

children.name: Dennery Segment
children.description: Developed in Saint Lucia in the early 2010s; heavily influenced by Angolan Kuduro, as well as incorporating elements of Zouk and Lucian drums alongside suggestive lyrics usually sung in Kwéyòl (Saint Lucian Creole).

children.name: Gwo ka
children.description: Developed in the island of Guadeloupe; driven by a group of gwo ka drums.

children.name: Haitian Music
children.description: Encompasses the styles of music developed by the Haitian people.

children.name: Kréyol djaz
children.description: Combines Jazz with various styles of French Caribbean Music.

children.name: Tumbélé
children.description: Combines Haitian Compas, Soukous and Cuban Guaguancó with the local style of Biguine.

children.name: Zouk
children.description: Fast-paced danceable pop that began in early 1980s French Antilles, merging and updating more traditional local genres.
